content.title: El Pacifico, gastronomic one way to Mexico

introduction.small: A real must while in town, Frankfurt's oldest Mexican restaurant looks like a traditional cantina in every way.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: El Pacifico, gastronomic one way to Mexico

paragraphs.text:
On a yellow wall behind a few wooden tables, Frida Kahlo gives visitors her now famously mysterious stare. Several portraits of the Mexican artist take up the wall space in this Frankfurt cantina. With its red and white facade and walls adorned with Aztec symbols, El Pacifico seems to have been purely and simply transported from Mexico. Every single detail has been thought out to make it look like an authentic corner of Central America: decoration, terrace arrangement, music… even the salt shakers are inspired from Mexican taverns. For pre-dinner drinks, ice margaritas – house speciality –, daiquiris and tequila sunrise cocktails – all to be enjoyed in moderation – cover the various tables of friends. The menu displays traditional gastronomy directly linked to El Pacifico's caliente atmosphere including fajitas, enchiladas, burritos, tacos, tortillas, guacamole and churro-based desserts…From Frankfurt, let your five senses explore Mexican culture in a refreshing change of scenery.

El Pacifico
Sandweg 79
60316 Frankfurt am Main

+49 (0)69 446 988

www.el-pacifico-ffm.de

Menu: around 23.50 EUR

content.title: Trendy stay at Moxy Frankfurt East

introduction.small: Moxy, Marriott's new brand, is designed for modern travellers. It opened a new location in Frankfurt, offering an unusual experience in a stylish setting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Trendy stay at Moxy Frankfurt East

paragraphs.text:
Sheltered in a large modern building close to the Main River wharves, near Frankfurt's city centre, Moxy Frankfurt East displays pink and black tones. In the lobby, a purple rhino stands on the counter, all shiny under colourful neon lights. The ground floor as a whole appears like a wonderfully relaxing spot with large sofas complete with trendy motley pillows, pink flamingos and foosball table. The space also offers nomadic workers to perform their daily tasks in muted comfort, akin to a start-up environment. In the bedrooms, contemporary design is key, with a touch of rock in small doses, bold paintings, a fuchsia hairdryer and small plastic duckies… pink too, of course! A trendy atmosphere that will please young and old alike.

Moxy Frankfurt East
Hanauer Landstraße 162
60314 Frankfurt am Main

+49 (0)69 5977 2140

www.moxy-hotels.marriott.com/hotels/frankfurt-east ﻿

Rooms: from 87 EUR

content.title: Lafleur, in the heart of a botanical garden

introduction.small: Contemporary cuisine with Mediterranean influences comes alive under chef Andreas Krolik.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lafleur, in the heart of a botanical garden

paragraphs.text:
Located in the Botanical Garden of Frankfurt, Restaurant Lafleur—a Relais & Châteaux selection— is a jewel of gastronomy. The two-star chef Andreas Krolik manages his kitchen with a master hand to serve dishes that are close to perfection. The dishes are contemporary, with a Mediterranean touch, and all products are regional. The specialty of the chef? Fish. The roasted turbot, with shiitake broth, pak choi, aubergine confit, seaweed and sesame, brilliantly blends many flavours and is both surprising and delicious. Andreas Krolik is also the only German starred chef to offer a complete vegetarian menu such as vegetable salad, spicy tofu, artichoke ravioli, asparagus, celery and mango.

Opening onto a garden of palm trees, the room is bathed in natural light. The violet colour allows the clarity of the immaculate white tablecloths to stand out. The restaurant is a stunning setting for exceptional cuisine.

Restaurant Lafleur
Palmengartenstraße 11
60325 Frankfurt am Main

+49 (0)69 900 29 100

www.restaurant-lafleur.de/en

Menu: from 125 EUR

content.title: The Gerbermühle: sleep in a restored mill

introduction.small: Seeped in history, this former flour mill saw the meeting of Goethe and his muse Marianne, before becoming the Gerbermühle boutique hotel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Gerbermühle: sleep in a restored mill

paragraphs.text:
On the banks of the Main River, an affluent of the Rhine, the Gerbermühle is a hotel laden with history. It had been a flour mill in the 16th century, was destroyed in the Second World War, then rebuilt and enlarged numerous times. It was here that Goethe met Marianne von Willemer who could become a source of inspiration to the German poet.

The hotel Gerbermühle was renovated with taste, combing what remains of the mill with very contemporary architecture open to the exterior. Inside, the look is spare with light tones and antique furniture spread with parsimony throughout the 18 rooms. Among them, are five suites named after personalities that had inspired Goethe during his life.

The winter garden holds the hotel restaurant, while the summer garden is very sought after when warm weather returns. In the evening discover the Tower Bar, niched into the intact part of the original mill. The brick walls give it real authenticity.

Gerbermühle
Gerbermühlstraße 105
60594 Frankfurt am Main

+49 (0)69 689 7779 0

www.gerbermuehle.de/en

Rooms: from 90 EUR

content.title: MyZeil: innovative architecture and a shopping paradise

introduction.small: Designed by the renowned Italian architect Massimiliano Fuksas, the spectacular glass architecture of MyZeil is an attraction in itself.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: MyZeil: innovative architecture and a shopping paradise

paragraphs.text:
This mall, located on the main Zeil shopping street, is ideal for shopaholics, but also architecture buffs.

The design is extremely kinetic: the glass panel facade, with a gaping hole in the centre reminiscent of a giant whirlpool gives way to a natural skylight. It's a mesmerising spectacle, day or night. Another attraction is the impressive 42-metre interior escalator, the longest in Europe.

All the big-prestige brands are represented on the eight levels of the mall, and there are many restaurants. If you prefer quiet, have lunch or a drink on the 7th floor terrace of the Zeilgalerie. The view over the city and its environs is stunning.

MyZeil
Zeil 106
60313 Frankfurt am Main

+49 (0)69 297 23970

www.myzeil.de

content.title: Visit the Goethe House

introduction.small:
Get inspired by visiting the home of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, one of Germany's most famous writers. Born in Frankfurt in 1749, he lived here until the age of 26.
.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Visit the Goethe House

paragraphs.text:
A few minutes from the historic centre is the Goethe House, home of the Romantic German writer and statesman from his birth until his departure to Weimar, where he died in 1832. The building was destroyed during World War II but entirely rebuilt with the original furniture, paintings, and books from the Goethe family.

The 18th-century bourgeois house has stained-glass windows, ceramic and wood stoves, polished staircases, carved solid-wood cabinets, plus the aforementioned paintings and family portraits. On the first floor is the writer's studio, with the modest little wooden desk on which he wrote his bestseller, The Sorrows of Young Werther. It's an inspiring place, and may just make you want to sit down and write your own romantic classic.

Frankfurt Goethe House
Großer Hirschgraben 23-25
60311 Frankfurt am Main

+49 (0)69 138 800

www.goethehaus-frankfurt.de

content.title: Lorsbacher Thal: the city's best tavern

introduction.small: A stay in Frankfurt is incomplete without dinner in a typical tavern. This fabulous spot serves traditional and generous cuisine, washed down with Apfelwein, the region's famous apple cider.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lorsbacher Thal: the city's best tavern

paragraphs.text:
The best taverns in Frankfurt are on the right bank of the Main, and the best of the best is the Lorsbacher Thal in old Sachsenhausen. Run for generations by the Dorn family, it is a lively place with rustic charm that specialises in Apfelwein cider, with more than 100 on the menu, all made with small apples from the region. The fare is traditional and delicious: pork chops and fried potatoes, sauerkraut, breaded schnitzels, frankfurters with cheese and onions, and the delicious green sauce that accompanies everything. Portions are served generously for strong appetites. The decor is just as traditional, with solid wood tables and benches, and the ambience is very convivial, with conversations between tables throughout the meal.

Lorsbacher Thal
Große Rittergasse 49
60594 Frankfurt am Main

+49 (0)69 6164 59

www.lorsbacher-thal.de

Menu: from 25 EUR

content.title: Frankfurt's opera traditions are second to none

introduction.small: Frankfurt's reputation as a city of the arts is due to its outstanding modern opera house, one of Europe's best. But the old opera house is as strong as ever.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Frankfurt's opera traditions are second to none

paragraphs.text:
The old opera house, inaugurated by Emperor Wilhelm I in 1880, hosted the first performances of Carl Orff's Carmina Burana. It was one of the most beautiful opera houses in Europe for nearly half a century.

Today, it is overshadowed by the spectacular Oper Frankfurt. But the old opera still has life in it. Partly destroyed during the Second World War, it was entirely rebuilt with local tax monies and generous donations.

Since its re-inauguration in 1981, it has hosted concerts and first-rate musicals. The Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra and London's Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields regularly play here. You can find the programme and buy tickets on the website or at the theatre. Visits are also organised.

Alte Oper Frankfurt
Konzert- und Kongresszentrum GmbH Opernplatz
60313 Frankfurt

+49 (0)69 13400

www.alteoper.de

content.title: Margarete: market-fresh food, creatively prepared

introduction.small: The colourful and modern atmosphere at Margarete restaurant seduces immediately. The emphasis in the kitchen is on fresh local produce and traditional Frankfurt home cooking, reinvented with flair.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Margarete: market-fresh food, creatively prepared

paragraphs.text:
A favourite spot for gastronomes looking for market-fresh local fare traditionally prepared with an abundance of creativity and flair. Everything is homemade from scratch. The restaurant is on one side, open for lunch and dinner, while the bar on the other side serves hearty breakfasts or a coffee to go.

The decor is welcoming, with modern wood furniture and industrial lamps in warm shades of blue.

Different menus are offered as well as various à la carte items, plus salads and soups of the day, all prepared with fresh products, most of them, like the wines, from the Frankfurt region.

Margarete
Braubachstraße 18-22
60311 Frankfurt am Main

+49 (0)69 1306 6650

www.margarete-restaurant.de/en/food-drink/

Menu: around 40 EUR

content.title: Römerberg: the historic centre of Frankfurt

introduction.small: Tourist central, this has also been the heart of the city since the 13th century. A lively, traditional quarter filled with older buildings.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Römerberg: the historic centre of Frankfurt

paragraphs.text:
The Römerberg, which means 'Mount of the Romans', is the oldest part of the city. Start your tour at the main square, the Römerplatz, where the town hall has proudly sat since 1405, perfectly aligned with its colourful half-timbered houses nearby.

The cathedral is here, too, and, in the middle of the square, the fountain of justice. Some of the buildings destroyed during the Second World War have been rebuilt almost identically to their former selves. The square has been a place of commerce since the early 11th century. The tradition continues today with the annual Frankfurt Book Fair, the world's most important publishing event.

From this strategic location, you can continue to the Eiserner Steg the ‘Iron Footbridge' across the Main, which will lead you to the Sachsenhausen area and its many taverns.

Römerberg
60311 Frankfurt am Main

+49 (0)69 212 38800

www.frankfurt-tourismus.de

content.title: Druckwasserwerk: an exceptional dining spot in a former water tower

introduction.small: Housed in a former water station, the Druckwasserwerk serves a traditional menu in an industrial setting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Druckwasserwerk: an exceptional dining spot in a former water tower

paragraphs.text:
Ideally located on the river, this trendy restaurant is as great looking inside as out. In fine weather, the terrace on the Main is jam-packed. In the evening, enjoy the scenery and this historic building with its high facade. Built in 1899 in a neo-Roman style, the red brick building is impressive for its height and volumes. It has kept its industrial spirit, with brick walls and blackened metal railings and dramatic, 13-metre high hanging red curtains. The contemporary and traditional menu is as varied as the clientele, featuring beef medallions with salmon from the fjords, a beetroot and basmati rice ratatouille, spätzle pasta in Roquefort cheese sauce and roasted onion… Whatever you choose, you will not regret coming to this outstanding restaurant that has been superbly restored.

Druckwasserwerk
Rotfeder-Ring 16,
60327 Frankfurt am Main

+49 (0)69 25628 7700

www.restaurant-druckwasserwerk.de

Menu: from 30 EUR

content.title: Zenzakan: a popular address with Asian flourishes

introduction.small: This huge place of over 2,000 square metres with a trendy atmosphere and subdued lighting is THE place to be seen, and also one of the country's best Asian restaurants.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Zenzakan: a popular address with Asian flourishes

paragraphs.text:
A runaway success since opening in 2009, Zenzakan attracts a loyal clientele, including the business crowd, every day and night. The ambience is Far Eastern, with many statues and giant busts of the Buddha. The decor is sumptuous, in brown, reddish-brown, and black tones with red-tinted lighting. Bouquets of branches, leaves, and flowers invade this refined and sublime temple. The food is also, of course, Asian-themed, with Vietnamese, Thai, and Japanese dishes. The street food tako yaki with dried skipjack flakes and spicy mayo, as well as the tuna tartare in Zenzakan sauce are divine, as is the Sichuan beef with rice.
Before or after dinner, head to the lounge bar, which offers a range of inventive cocktails, such as a mojito made with lemongrass and a second version made with Japanese plum wine.

Zenzakan
Taunusanlage 15
60325 Frankfurt am Main

+49 (0)69 9708 6908

www.mook-group.de/zenzakan/

Menu: from 50 EUR

content.title: High up the Main Tower

introduction.small: Feel a thrill atop the Main Tower with 360º views of the city and its surrounding hills.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: High up the Main Tower

paragraphs.text:
To get an unrivalled look at Frankfurt's splendid architecture, the best point of view publicly available is the Main Tower, a skyscraper inaugurated in 1999. Amid the buildings of the banking centre and almost 200 metres high, it provides a dizzying overview of the urban landscape.

To go to the viewing platform, take the elevator to the 54th floor. Within seconds you will be propelled to the top of the glass tower. It's a great show and a dazzling view.

To get over your emotions and take in the view for a longer while, stop for a snack in the tower restaurant on the 53th floor.

Main Tower
Neue Mainzer Strasse 52-58
60311 Frankfurt am Main

+49 (0)69 3650 4878

www.maintower.de/en/

content.title: Villa Kennedy: a romantic and luxurious setting

introduction.small: Contemporary decor, luxurious services, and one of the best spas make this an exceptional hotel, ideally located in the heart of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Villa Kennedy: a romantic and luxurious setting

paragraphs.text:
The former Villa Speyer, an exemplary model of Neoclassical architecture, is now the Villa Kennedy, completely restored, redesigned, and expanded, and yet still showing traces of yesteryear. The ancient statues in the courtyard garden, for example, offer a romantic and peaceful haven.

Past and present, charm and modernity all blend flawlessly in the hotel's light and airy spaces. The 163 rooms (of which 36 are suites) are split between the villa and the modern wing. All are classically decorated in shades of beige and taupe, with superb sofas covered in natural fabrics. The innate elegance extends into the bathrooms, where the walls are covered with mosaics. The luxurious open garden spa is a Zen oasis, very popular with Frankfurters, with pool, fitness centre, eight massage rooms, and more than 120 treatments offered.

The JFK Bar attracts a lively and glamorous clientele, as does Gusto, the hotel's excellent Italian restaurant.

Villa Kennedy
Kennedy Allee 70
60596 Frankfurt

+49 (0)69 7171 20

www.roccofortehotels.com/fr/hotels-and-resorts/villa-kennedy/

Rooms: from 375 EUR

content.title: Culture breeding ground at Museum Embankment

introduction.small: Both sides of the Main are lined with renowned museums, covering everything from architecture to film and painting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Culture breeding ground at Museum Embankment

paragraphs.text:
These exhibition venues, alongside the river, are the pride of the city planners, and the area has become, in recent years, a cultural centre and a privileged promenade. It is especially fun on Saturday mornings, when it plays host to a large flea market. The museums themselves are all great; they vary in size, renown, and subject, but the best among them are the Städel, the Giersch Museum, the Museum of German Cinema, the German Architecture Museum, and the Museum of Telecommunications.

If you had to choose only one, there's no hesitation head to the 200-year-old Städel, home to one of the most beautiful art collections in the world, covering more than 700 years of European art, including Renaissance, Baroque, and more contemporary masterpieces. Rembrandt, Picasso, Giacometti, Joseph Beuys, and Gerhard Richter are among the artists represented.

Städel Museum
Schaumainkai 63,
60596 Frankfurt am Main

+49 (0)69 6050 98200

www.staedelmuseum.de

content.title: The Pure: minimalist design in white-on-white decor

introduction.small: In the heart of the business district, immerse yourself in a world of purity and whiteness in this boutique hotel of 50 luminous and relaxing rooms.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Pure: minimalist design in white-on-white decor

paragraphs.text:
The Pure is the aptly named creation of interior designer Oana Rosen, who chose a white monochrome atmosphere to expand upon the volumes and high ceilings of a building that once housed a textile factory. The same concept was behind the choice of marble or white leather furniture.

The rooms are very Zen, with dark-oak parquets, ‘cathedral' ceilings (nearly four metres high), white leather headboards, and brown wooden bed frames. The luminous bedrooms are filled with white orchids.

It is a popular nightspot, when the hotel sparkles with energy, and its facade, bar, and outside terrace are lit up with orangey-yellow lights.

The Pure
Niddastraße 86
60329 Frankfurt am Main

+49 (0)69 710 4570

www.the-pure.de

Rooms: from 80 EUR

content.title: In the heart of the Stock Exchange

introduction.small: A guided tour of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange is a must.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: In the heart of the Stock Exchange

paragraphs.text:
Frankfurt is as famous as a financial centre as it is for its eponymous sausage. The best way to discover this intriguing world of high rollers is to visit the Stock Exchange.

From Monday to Friday, alone or in groups, you can sit in on a 45-minute presentation while observing brokers and traders at work through large display windows. It's also worth visiting just for its architecture: the 19th-century building is known locally as the ‘Cathedral of the Capitalists' because of its 43-metre-high dome. Two bronze statues adorn the outer square: a bull, the traditional symbol of a rise in stock prices, and a bear, the traditional symbol of market decline.

Börse Frankfurt
Börsenpl. 4
60313 Frankfurt am Main

+ 49 (0)69 21 10

www.deutsche-boerse.com

content.title: Steigenberger Frankfurter Hof: a classic, still as popular as ever.

introduction.small: Founded in 1876 and now a historic monument, this hotel is a must. Ideally located in the heart of the financial district, its fine-dining restaurant draws the banking and business community.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Steigenberger Frankfurter Hof: a classic, still as popular as ever.

paragraphs.text:
This stately Neoclassical institution has seen its share of celebrities over the last century and a half. Everyone in Frankfurt knows this immense palace, among the best hotels of the city. Its strategic position in the business district, four excellent restaurants, cigar bar, and luxurious spa assure its continued success. The lobby is elegant and cosy, with very contemporary decor.

The 261 rooms and 42 suites have all been recently updated in a classic and refined style with beige, taupe, and chestnut tones. Gastronomes will appreciate the sublime breakfast.

In the evening, the lounge bar is an exquisite place, especially for cigar smokers. The must is the award-winning, Michelin-starred French restaurant. Other pleasures are to be found in the spa and Turkish bath, decorated with gorgeous iridescent mosaics.

Steigenberger Frankfurter Hof
Kaiserstraße
60311 Frankfurt am Main

+49 (0)69 21502

www.steigenberger.com/hotels/alle-hotels/deutschland/frankfurt/steigenberger-frankfurter-hof

Rooms: from 239 EUR

content.title: New address for the European Central Bank

introduction.small: Inaugurated in March 2015, the new headquarters of the ECB is a 3D architectural wonder by the Viennese architect Wolf D. Prix.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: New address for the European Central Bank

paragraphs.text:
Change, of course, has come for Frankfurt bankers, who have left the Eurotower city centre and moved east to Ostend, down on the river Main. The formerly quiet area has already seen a bump in square-metre prices.

The two twisted towers of steel, glass, and concrete, which took ten years to build, are 185 metres high, with dramatic views over the city. The technology on the 45 floors is cutting-edge: lifts that climb to the top in seconds; building heating provided by recycling the heat generated by computers; and toilets flushed with recycled rainwater. The gym is very popular.

Visit the Council Chambers on the 41st floor, which has a ceiling decorated with a stylised map of Europe and spectacular views through its three glass walls.

European Central Bank
Sonnemannstraße 20
60314 Frankfurt am Main

+49 (0)69 13440

www.ecb.europa.eu

content.title: 25hours Hotel by Levi's: an unusual encounter

introduction.small: The trendiest hotel of the moment offers boho chic at a bargain price.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: 25hours Hotel by Levi's: an unusual encounter

paragraphs.text:
Fruit of an alliance between the 25hours German hotel group and the famous jeans brand Levi's, this trendy hotel attracts a young and creative clientele. The look is playful, starting with the cardboard-like facade. The quirkiness continues in the lobby, with its vintage, mismatched chairs, cowboy-boot lamps, and printed graphics. At the reception, you can choose the size of your room: small, medium or large, depending on your budget. 76 rooms are spread over six floors all done up in denim from floor to ceiling. Midnight blue, denim blue, indigo blue, light blue, faded stonewashed blue – it's all here. The hotel's restaurant is open late, and the rooftop terrace offers a captivating view.

25hours Hotel by Levis
Niddastraße 58
60329 Frankfurt am Main

+49 (0)69 256 6770

www.25hours-hotels.com

Rooms: from 7164 EUR

content.title: A discovery cruise on the Main

introduction.small: See the city anew by taking a cruise and gliding along between verdant riverbanks.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A discovery cruise on the Main

paragraphs.text:
This fascinating boat trip lets you to see the city in a new light. Trips of 50 minutes or 100 minutes leave from Eiserner Steg dock next to the Iron Footbridge, and travel up the river to the locks of Offenbach and Griesheim. The guided trip takes about a 90 minutes, and it's a great way to discover the city and its landmarks.

For those tempted to visit the surroundings of Frankfurt, Primus Linie organises day trips to the Rheingau region, where the best Riesling wines are produced.

Beautiful castles and picturesque towns are passed along the way. It's especially magical in the spring or summer.

Primus-Linie
Mainkai 36
60311 Frankfurt

+49 (0)69 13 38 370

www.primus-linie.de

content.title: Visit the picturesque palm garden

introduction.small: This green oasis in the heart of the city is a favourite spot for the people of Frankfurt. Its greenhouses, little train, and lake make for a lovely visit.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Visit the picturesque palm garden

paragraphs.text:
The Palmengarten (palm garden) is a gorgeous botanical garden that changes with the seasons.

Created in 1868, its 22 hectares are covered with lawns, flowers, and bushes. In 14 greenhouses filled with tropical and subtropical plants, every climactic zone is perfectly reproduced, including a lush tropical rainforest; a hot, humid monsoon forest of mangroves; and an arid desert of giant cacti.

Outdoors, Goethe's garden is also worth a visit. It pays tribute to this prince of poets, a great lover of gardens, who wrote an ode to ginkgo. In spring, exquisite roses spread their delicate fragrance in this wonderfully exotic realm.

Palmengarten
Siesmayerstraße 61
60323 Frankfurt am Main

+49 (0)69 2123 3939

www.palmengarten.de

content.title: Roomers: chic design hotel for a high-end clientele

introduction.small: This former office building, completely restored by the famous designer Oana Rosen, has become one of the trendiest hotels in Frankfurt.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Roomers: chic design hotel for a high-end clientele

paragraphs.text:
This hotel of 116 rooms of contemporary design is a concentrate of modernity and elegance. From the lobby to the rooms, luxury and simplicity are the order of the day. The ultimate focus is the comfort of the client. A cosy atmosphere prevails in design-savvy rooms, with soft lighting and steel headboards on upholstered beds in shades of taupe and chestnut brown.

Noble materials such as wood, metal, stone, and leather coexist in perfect harmony. The same attention to detail is evident in the dark stone and polished steel bathrooms, which are equipped with superb freestanding bathtubs that you'll never want to leave unless, of course, it's to go to the beautifully appointed spa or the landscaped, 600-square-metre rooftop-terrace bar, voted the best bar in Frankfurt.

Roomers
Gutleutstraße 85
60329 Frankfurt am Main

+49 (0)69 271 3420

www.roomers-frankfurt.com

Rooms: from 126 EUR
